56. One Aristonidas strove with his senses
to depict well in a bronze Figure
(an unusual thing!) the emotion of wrath,
of the angry and stubborn
Athamas, King of Thebes,
who had his own Son Learchus
thrown to his death from a high crag.
[The artist] depicted him in a seated pose.
left-middleExample of wrath and grief depicted in a Figure of cast bronze, with Iron mixed in the face.

57. Nevertheless in such a form as if to behold
that he was coming to his senses,
and repented, with grieving sorrow,
such a murderous act devised by him.
So, he mixed his bronze with iron,
with foresight, to give this face
a blushing redness, bewildered and wild,
as the iron became rusty.

58. This Figure was still displayed in the Greek
city of Thebes in Plinyâ€™s time,
when the rusty Iron, mingled
with the gleaming Bronze, revealed
the flush of confusion in that face.
Now then, O Painters, hearing the greatness
of sincerity and effort in these matters,
Let your sleeping spirit awaken.

59. You can more aptly and easily
achieve your goal, straight and without error,
painting and repainting with all your colors
so that your Figures almost utter from their mouths
all the emotions hidden in their hearts.
In a wrathful head you can paint two burning coals
sheltering under two dark brows,
that bulge high over smoldering thunder.
left-middlePainters have a great advantage with all manner of colors.

60. Just as Michelangelo, following Dante,
painted the Captain of the ship of hell
in his Last Judgment, one should place
the iris of the eye surrounded by white edges,
above as below, through both exposures.
the surface of the Face should be greatly bloated,
red and fiery from raging heat;
the brow should be furrowed like the head of a Lion.

61. Gaunt Envy, full of jealousy,
cadaverous and wan, savage, bitter,
artfully described by Ovid,
banished to her cold, dark, foul dwelling.
